Comment: Solid, and usually leading to slow play.
The Budapest Gambit, a relatively new opening at the time.
The automatic response, then and now.
A rarer variant is 3... N-N5, threatening to win back the Pawn at once.
To prevent a Black minor piece from occupying QN5.
Opening a line for the QB and threatening to recapture the gambited Pawn.
To preserve his material advantage, White consents to the exchange.
Now Black has a considerable advantage in development and a centralized Knight in return for the Pawn.
The game-losing blunder. 6 B-Q2, 6 N-Q2 or 6 N-KR3 would all have prevented Black's winning tactical maneuver.
Decisive. If the Q moves away, Black wins the Exchange with 7... NxR. If 7 KxN, 7... BxP ch wins the White Q. Warren of course resigns at once.
